commit_message:
Reduced cluster and release information in deployment_info

Reduced cluster and release attributes which are added to
deployment_info on serialization

Change-Id: I98a960ad4b4c1ac12f25059e9b429fdca97cffb4
Closes-Bug: 1618002
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/88/362088/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: release = self.cluster_db.release release_info = { 'name': release.name, 'version': release.version, 'operating_system': release.operating_system, } cluster_info = { "id": self.cluster_db.id, "name": self.cluster_db.name, "fuel_version": self.cluster_db.fuel_version, "status": self.cluster_db.status, "mode": self.cluster_db.mode } for node_info in serialized: self.assertEqual(cluster_info, node_info['cluster']) self.assertEqual(release_info, node_info['release']) self.assertEqual(['compute'], serialized[0]['roles']) self.assertEqual([consts.TASK_ROLES.master], serialized[1]['roles'])
deleted_lines: for node_info in serialized: self.assertEqual( objects.Cluster.to_dict(self.cluster_db), node_info['cluster'] ) self.assertEqual( objects.Release.to_dict(self.cluster_db.release), node_info['release'] ) self.assertEqual( ['compute'], serialized[0]['roles'] ) self.assertEqual( [consts.TASK_ROLES.master], serialized[1]['roles'] )

subject: Changed an assert to more specific assert method
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-30 01:08:39.000000000', 'files': ['ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_plugins_extra_hardware.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector/commit/37150ca0a3a9467c6620637eacf7d3efe0d9cb12', 'message': 'Changed an assert to more specific assert method

Following OpenStack Style Guidelines [1], I changed:
assertFalse(sth in sth) to assertNotIn(sth, sth).

After this change, a more specific message is shown on error.

[1]: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#unit-tests-and-assertraises

Change-Id: I929900eb5dc48eb04b541e387b70d69c4865ca03
'}]
commit_message:
Changed an assert to more specific assert method

Following OpenStack Style Guidelines [1], I changed:
assertFalse(sth in sth) to assertNotIn(sth, sth).

After this change, a more specific message is shown on error.

[1]: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#unit-tests-and-assertraises

Change-Id: I929900eb5dc48eb04b541e387b70d69c4865ca03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/11/362511/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertNotIn('data', introspection_data)

commit_message:
Documentation for translation in horizon

This document describes the overview architecture of how
translation works in Horizon. It also covers how one can
use it in their code.

Change-Id: I93063698cb1fc43f22e2fd7960e8a38ee423dab7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/08/328008/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =================== Horizon Translation =================== What is the point of translating my code? ========================================= You introduced an awesome piece of code and revel in your glorious accomplisment. Suddenly your world comes crashing down when a core hands you a -1 because your code is not translated. What gives? If you are writing software meant for a global audience, such is the case with enterprise level software, you will want to ensure that it is translated so that other people around the world are able to use it. Adding translation to your code is not that hard and the benefits of it out weights the work you have to put in. Making strings translatable =========================== To take your strings translatable, you simple need to mark it so that horizon can locate and extract it into a POT file. From there, something magical happens and a PO file is generated containing all of the translatable strings in different locales. When a user from another locale visits your page, your string is replaced with the correct translated version. Here is a quick run down of what happens once you mark some strings for translation. This is done via our run_script and the resulting POT file is then picked up in Zanata. Once it gets translated by translators into specific languages, a translation patch will get propose to horizon for review. In Django --------- To translate a string, simply wrap the string around one of the gettext variants. Them examples below show you how to do translation for various scenarious, such as interpolation, contextual markers, translation comments, etc. .. Note :: In the example below, we substituted **ugettext** as **_**. This is a common alias for gettext or any of its variants. In Django, you have to explicitly spell it out in the import. :: from django.utils.translation import pgettext from django.utils.translation import ugettext as _ from django.utils.translation import ungettext class IndexView(request): # Single translation _("Images") # Plural translation ungettext( 'there is %(count)d object', 'there are %(count)d objects', count) % { 'count': count } # Interpolated translation output = _('Today is %(mood)s.') % mood # Contextual markers pgettext("the month name", "May") # Translators: This message appears for translators! ugettext("Welcome translators.") In Django templates ------------------- To use translation in your template, make sure you load the i18n module. To translate a line of text, use the **trans** template tag. If you need to translate a block of text, use the **blocktrans** template tag. Sometimes, it is helpful to provide some context via the **comment** template tag. There a number of other tags and filters at your disposal should you need to use them. For more information, see the Django docs. :: {% extends 'base.html' %} {% load i18n %} {% block title %} {% trans "Images" %} {% endblock %} {% block main %} {% comment %}Translators: Images is an OpenStack resource{% endcomment %} {% blocktrans with amount=images.length %} There are {{ amount }} images available for display. {% endblocktrans %} {% endblock %} In Javascript ------------- todo In AngularJS templates ---------------------- todo Overview and Architecture ========================= This section explains how the underlying message extraction work and the technologies that Horizon uses to piece it all together. [Insert picture] todo References ========== .. [#] https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/topics/i18n/translation/ .. [#] http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/creators.html#enabling-translation-infrastructure

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

In some part in the code we import objects.
Openstack style guideline recommends to import only modules.

commit_message:
Implement container bind mount for all logs

All of the log directories for all containers will now be bind mounted to the
host. This change ensures that containers are not running into an issue with
Full file systems due to logs which is common when a container is backed by
a blocked device (lvm, zfs, btrfs).

Closes-Bug: #1588051
Change-Id: I25a481c0409f1a45494a8668f00c5393672e853c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

it.

commit_message:
Cleanup tox.ini

Remove old and unused constraints environments.

this does not enable constraints (they were not enabled before) since
ironic-ui is not part of global requirements process.

Change-Id: I3f541f1e6322d229f0136f317cc14d83f2f75186

commit_message:
Do not set segmentation_id in Neutron Net as a direct property

In current implementation of tosca.nodes.network.Network translation,
the property of segmentation_id is included, but it doesn't exist in hot
syntax(provider network informantion can be included in property of
value_specs), so it will be deleted from current code.

Change-Id: I9a59f8afb3347e1d9346707d1a6ec01d2023f7b9
Signed-off-by: shangxdy <shang.xiaodong@zte.com.cn>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-translator refs/changes/70/360670/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: network_name: test_net network_type: vxlan segmentation_id: 100

commit_message:
Added Support for Unsupported Types

Checks for the unsupported type in the template.
Raises an error if a type is a valid TOSCA type but
mappting to HOT is not yet provided in the translator.

Co-Authored-By: Sahdev Zala <spzala@us.ibm.com>

Change-Id: If6e821b1b2db4f01dd302ff068f3d4f0b73661b2
Partially-Implements: blueprint unsupported-type-validation

commit_message:
Fix integration tests

Images table in openstack dashboard renders
by Angular now. There are no integration tests
in Horizon for test this table, but there is
possibility to configure table to old-style.
In this patch I ovveride the configurations
provided by the panels and force a 'legacy' setting.
Based upon change: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/349020/

Change-Id: I3382bed3ff516a14d5b72ed3a7bedc409b0de8eb

commit_message:
Add fuel2 diagnostic snapshot commands

This patch adds commands that allow to manipulate
with diagnostic snapshot process creation:

   fuel2 snapshot get-default-config
   fuel2 snapshot create
   fuel2 snapshot get-link

DocImpact

Change-Id: I59542eba922d793406c50b864b1cd0c416c7c891

commit_message:
Fix click into node detail bug

Reproduce:
1 Open Cluster/Nodes page
2 Click "Create Node", input node name, such as "node1", select a profile
  and do not select a cluster.
3 There will display the node "test" in the table. Click the node "test"
  into the detail page, there will cast error in the top right corner.

Change-Id: Id8d6c8cf9a2e367e21e81f4bf8656dd45c496910
Closes-Bug: #1606772

commit_message:
Show name_or_id when profile name is white space

Reproduce:
1 Open Cluster/Profiles page
2 Create a profile with name "white space"
3 Then there will display a profile with name "white space" in the table.
  But this profile could not be clicked into it's detail page.
So there should show profile's name_or_id when it's name is "white space".

Change-Id: I0c4882e2a7ba1c51eebf982cb87ed65cb74e96bf
Closes-Bug: #1605146

added_lines: CLI must also be made to the ``openstack`` CLI and possibly the OpenStack Python SDK. Users of the neutron client's command extensions should start their transition to the OSC plugin system. See the developer guide section below for more information on this step.gap, a few critical questions for developers during this transition are "Which CLI do I change?", "Where does my CLI belong?", and "Which Python library do I change?" The answer depends on the state of a command and the state of the overall transition. Details are outlined in the tables below. Early stages of the transition will require dual maintenance.| Advanced Feature | Yes | python-neutronclient | | | | (``neutronclient/osc/v2/<advanced_feature>``) || Core | No | python-openstackclient |**Which Python library do I change?** +-------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+ | OpenStack Project for ``openstack`` Commands | Python Library to Change | +=================================================+===============================================+ | python-openstackclient | python-openstacksdk | +-------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+ | python-neutronclient | python-neutronclient | +-------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+ | Other | Applicable project owning network resource | +-------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+ name conflicts. The `network` prefix must be used to avoid name conflicts if the command object name is highly likely to have an ambiguous meaning. Developers should get new command objects and actions approved by the OSC team before proceeding with the implementation. The "Core" group includes network resources that provide core ``neutron`` project features (e.g. network, subnet, port, etc.) and not advanced features (e.g. dynamic routing, trunk, etc.) or services (FWaaS, LBaaS, VPNaaS, etc.). The "Other" group applies projects other than ``neutron``. Contact the neutron PTL or core team with questions on network resource classification.file.
deleted_lines: CLI must also be made to the ``openstack`` CLI and the OpenStack Python SDK. Enhancements to the networking support in the OpenStack Python SDK will be handled via bugs. Users of the neutron client's command extensions should start their transition to the OSC plugin system. See the developer guide section below for more information on this step.gap, a couple critical questions for developers during this transition are "Which CLI do I change?" and "Where does my CLI belong?" The answer depends on the state of a command and the state of the overall transition. Details are outlined in the tables below. Early stages of the transition will require dual maintenance. Eventually, dual maintenance will be reduced to critical bug fixes only with feature requests only being made to the ``openstack`` CLI.| Core | No | python-openstackclient || Dynamic Routing | Yes | python-neutronclient | | | | (``neutronclient/osc/v2/dynamic_routing``) |name conflicts. Developers should get new command objects and actions approved by the OSC team before proceeding with the implementation. The "Core" group includes network resources that provide ``neutron`` project features (i.e. not advanced service or other features). Examples in the "Core" group include: network, subnet, port, etc.file. ``openstack`` networking commands outside python-openstackclient are encouraged but not required to use the OpenStack Python SDK.

commit_message:
Remove the deprecated access to Exception message

Deprecated since Python 2.6, removed in Python 3.
Even if APIException from saharaclient provides an error_message
property, this seems the normal way to access the message from
children of Exception.

Change-Id: Icc23553649280bfd8c1c376be2492b08f6388a91

commit_message:
Pecan: Handle member actions

The legacy pecan uri routing allowed the definition of member actions.
These are API resources that hang off a particular resource_id.  An
example of this is:

PUT /routers/{router_id}/add_router_interface

The legacy seemed to do only PUTs and GETs so that has been implemented
in Pecan.  Other methods can easily be added if needed.

Also, with the generic handling of this came the decision to remove the
specific pecan routers controller because it's only function was to
facilitate its member actions to work.  It is no longer needed.

Change-Id: If776476545edca0c4c43ce3969bb5d1af79f4382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/81/344581/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: member_actions = legacy_controller.member_actions parent_resource=parent_resource, member_actions=member_actions)

subject: Specification for tripleo-lldp-validation blueprint
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-13 22:07:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/commit/2b48e894ba517b8ecf9c5cd86b0403a53f3db576', 'message': 'Specification for tripleo-lldp-validation blueprint

This spec describes the tripleo-lldp-validation from this blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-lldp-validation

The feature should gather information from Swift that was gathered
during introspection, and present a report of the physical network
topology based on LLDP data. This will make deployment troubleshooting
easier, and will provide a basis for future automation.

Change-Id: I129080d2fee0f08155afecdaf6a94a2e535d536d

commit_message:
Specification for tripleo-lldp-validation blueprint

This spec describes the tripleo-lldp-validation from this blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-lldp-validation

The feature should gather information from Swift that was gathered
during introspection, and present a report of the physical network
topology based on LLDP data. This will make deployment
troubleshooting easier, and will provide a basis for future
automation.

Change-Id: I129080d2fee0f08155afecdaf6a94a2e535d536d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/03/329203/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== TripleO LLDP Validation ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-lldp-validation Currently TripleO leverages Ironic-Inspector to do introspection on hardware nodes. As part of this process, LLDP data is collected and stored in the extra_hardware blob in Swift for the node. Today we don't do anything with this data, but it should be parsed and reported on in a human-readable form so that the operator can use this data for validation. Problem Description =================== A detailed description of the problem: * Deployment networking is one of the most difficult parts of any OpenStack deployment. A single misconfigured port or loose cable can derail an entire multi-rack deployment. * Given the first point, we should work to automate validation and troubleshooting where possible. * We already collect the relevant LLDP data, but do nothing with it. Proposed Change =============== Overview -------- The goal is to expose existing LLDP data that is collected during introspection, and provide this data in a format that is useful for the deployer. Alternatives ------------ There are many network management utilities that use CDP or LLDP data to validate the physical networking. Some of these are open source, but none are integrated with OpenStack. Alternative approaches that do not use LLDP are typically vendor-specific and require specific hardware support. Cumulus has a solution which works with multiple vendors' hardware, but that solution requires running their custom OS on the Ethernet switches. Another approach which is common is to perform collection of the switch configurations to a central location, where port configurations can be viewed, or in some cases even altered and remotely pushed. The problem with this approach is that the switch configurations are hardware and vendor-specific, and typically a network engineer is required to read and interpret the configuration. A unified approach that works for all common switch vendors is preferred, along with a unified reporting format. Security Impact --------------- The physical network report provides a roadmap to the underlying network structure. This could prove handy to an attacker who was unaware of the existing topology. On the other hand, the information about physical network topology is less valuable than information about logical topology to an attacker. LLDP contains some information about both physical and logical topology, but the logical topology is limited to VLAN IDs. The network topology report should be considered sensitive but not critical. No credentials or shared secrets are revealed in the data collected by ironic-inspector. Other End User Impact --------------------- This report will hopefully reduce the troubleshooting time for nodes with failed network deployments. Performance Impact ------------------ If this report is produced as part of the ironic-inspector workflow, then it will increase the time taken to introspect each node by a negligible amount, perhaps a few seconds. If this report is called by the operator on demand, it will have no performance impact on other components. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers may want additional information than the per-node LLDP report. There may be some use in providing aggregate reports, such as the number of nodes with a specific configuration of interfaces and trunked VLANs. This would help to highlight outliers or misconfigured nodes. There have been discussions about adding automated switch configuration in TripleO. This would be a mechanism whereby deployers could produce the Ethernet switch configuration with a script based on a configuration template. The deployer would provide specifics like the number of nodes and the configuration per node, and the script would generate the switch configuration to match. In that case, the LLDP collection and analysis would function as a validator for the automatically generated switch port configurations. Developer Impact ---------------- Since this report will be based on the JSON schema that ironic-inspector produces, the reporting tool will have to be updated when the ironic- inspector team changes the data produced during introspection. Implementation ============== Some notes about implementation: * The extra_hadware blob is stored in Swift, this can be retrieved with the Swift client. * The data will be returned as a JSON, with more data than we care about. The 'jq' utility can parse out the relevant section and pretty print it. * Although the initial implementation can return a human-readable report, other outputs should be available for automation, such as YAML. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: dsneddon <dsneddon@redhat.com> Other contributors: bfournie <bfournie@redhat.com> Work Items ---------- * script to grab extra_hardware blob from Swift * jq query to extract the relevant information from the extra_hardware blob * per-node reports * aggregate reports Testing ======= Since this is a report that is supposed to benefit the operator, perhaps the best way to include it in CI is to make sure that the report gets logged by the Undercloud. Then the report can be reviewed in the log output from the CI run. In fact, this might benefit the TripleO CI process, since hardware issues on the network would be easier to troubleshoot without having access to the bare metal console. Documentation Impact ==================== Unknown. References ==========

commit_message:
Make Astute depend on Timmy

Since Timmy is required for Astute to perform diagnostic snapshot
creation it should be made a dependency.

Closes-Bug: #1617970

Add security group to port spec

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/67/194267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ====================================== Adding security group to pre-created port ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/add-security-group-to-port This blueprint adds a new heat resource that can add a security group to a pre-created port. Problem description =================== Neutron 'OS::Neutron::Port' resource can be used to create port with security-groups, but it is not possible to add a security group to a port that was created out side of template by an operator. Proposed change =============== To add security group to a pre-created port, I propose adding a new resource 'OS::Neutron::AttachSecurityGroupToPort' like below.:: attach_sec_group: type: OS::Neutron::AttachSecurityGroupToPort properties: security_group: { get_resource: default_sec_group } port: { get_attr: [ my_server, networks, public, 0, port ] } Here security group ID and port ID are provided to AttachSecurityGroupToPort resource. Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Vijendar Komalla Milestones ---------- liberty-1 Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ None

commit_message:
Adds exchange declaration on sender's side

When you send message to exchange which is not exist current
channel is closed and you need to reconnect. This is undesired.
Also this patch separate sending fanout message and call/cast
messages and don't raise exception if exchange doesn't exist
for fanout messages.

Change-Id: Ia556d0c1b219387892007925bb437664aaaccb69
(cherry picked from commit 89cc47e)

commit_message:
Enable log collection after functional testing

This change enables log collection within the gate so that further analysis
on gate tasks can be performed post build. This is very useful when
debugging problems.

Change-Id: I376b5bf2d395314de5ed22489277eacd2fc32839
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest refs/changes/62/362562/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

commit_message:
Enable log collection after functional testing

This change enables log collection within the gate so that further analysis
on gate tasks can be performed post build. This is very useful when
debugging problems.

added_lines: # Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true' bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

commit_message:
Duplicate utils code in kuryr-lib and kuryr-libnetwork

Since commit[1] had renamed kuryr utils to kuryr-libnetwork utils,
but there are some duplicate codes leave behind in old repo.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/337350

Change-Id: I6bf0c5517b4742ee4ca77d34bdf94db9d8b0e29a
Closes-Bug: #1618012

commit_message:
Use summary field for sending task summary

Currently Astute uses 'custom' field for sending task summary and
it's wrong, because Nailgun searching for 'summary' field.

Change-Id: Ieb01161d92f82768cbc5057b5dbb501fcf53a74f
(cherry picked from commit aca2bf3cd1f053019d25fb6ad9ea20d46f54bd38)

commit_message:
[Trivial] Fix Share Network details field

The field "Share Servers on this network" is too long to fit
the column. Since it's quite evident to find share servers of
the network which details tab is opened, it seems logical to
shorten the field name to "Share Servers".

Change-Id: I435993b2a39cdad5b321a6834cc773669acc4885

commit_message:
Use upper constraints in tox installs

Openstack infra now supports upper constraints for all jobs.
This patch adds upper constaints for test environment setup.

Change-Id: I86312653e2b044e7180a9201addd48b29aa61bba
Closes-Bug: #1596246
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila-ui refs/changes/12/360412/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install_command = pip install -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt} {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
Add release note to warn about os-brick lock dir

Not really a new bug, but turns out this wasn't generally known
or documented anywhere. As a heads up for folks we'll put in a
known issue into the release note for N.

Change-Id: Icc06da4399446b6d537aac9ee4d00df8226580c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/02/354502/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- issues: - When running Nova Compute and Cinder Volume or Backup services on the same host they must use a shared lock directory to avoid volume operation failures. This is done by setting "lock_path" in the "oslo_concurrency" section of nova.conf and cinder.conf.

commit_message:
List system dependencies for running common tests

Add a bindep.txt file containing a cross-platform list
of dependencies needed for running included tox-based tests. Also
include a tox environment for convenience calling the bindep[*]
utility to list any missing system requirements, and simplify the
contributor documentation to recommend this rather than embedding an
ad-hoc list of package names in an untestable document.

This change is self-testing.

[*] http://docs.openstack.org/infra/bindep/

Change-Id: I7c18b0921c39b99df89f2c356208303c2bad5a97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/72/200672/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Getting the code ```````````````` Grab the code from git:: git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/nova cd nova The first step of this process is to install the system (not Python) packages that are required. Following are instructions on how to do this on Linux and on the Mac. Install the prerequisite packages listed in the other-requirements.txt file. On Debian-based distributions (e.g., Debian/Mint/Ubuntu):: sudo apt-get install python-pip sudo pip install tox tox -e bindep sudo apt-get install <indicated missing package names> sudo yum install python-pip sudo pip install tox tox -e bindep sudo yum install <indicated missing package names> sudo zypper in python-pip sudo pip install tox tox -e bindep sudo zypper in <indicated missing package names>
deleted_lines: The first step of this process is to install the system (not Python) packages that are required. Following are instructions on how to do this on Linux and on the Mac.Install the prerequisite packages. On Ubuntu:: sudo apt-get install python-dev libssl-dev python-pip git-core libxml2-dev libxslt-dev pkg-config libffi-dev libpq-dev libmysqlclient-dev graphviz libsqlite3-dev python-tox sudo yum install python-devel openssl-devel python-pip git gcc libxslt-devel mysql-devel postgresql-devel libffi-devel libvirt-devel graphviz sqlite-devel sudo pip-python install tox sudo zypper in gcc git libffi-devel libmysqlclient-devel libvirt-devel libxslt-devel postgresql-devel python-devel python-pip python-tox python-virtualenvGetting the code ```````````````` Once you have the prerequisite system packages installed, the next step is to clone the code. Grab the code from git:: git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/nova cd nova

commit_message:
Replace use of eval with ast.literal_eval

literal_eval supports a limited subset of Python, and is therefore
safer than eval.

Close-bug: 1414529
Change-Id: Ib6145408360fa57cccc8d77c590a203e5088b193
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/13/275513/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import ast #params = eval(exc.details[3]) params = ast.literal_eval(exc.details[3])

commit_message:
Provide more duplicate VLAN network error info

When user tries to create a network which VLAN ID is already
used by another network, Network object will throw a DuplicateVlan
exception. However, when the exception get propagate to the API level,
it is only treated as a regular exception. This fix is to treat Duplicate
Vlan exception as a special exception (similar to DuplicateCidr) so that
users know more about what kind of duplicated setting they configured.

Change-Id: Ib2f7bc90957d4ae5647adbbda05a87195549374d
Closes-Bug: #1420112
Co-Authored-By: kahou Lei<kahou82@gmail.com>

subject: Hyper-V: properly handle shared storage during migrations
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-28 16:10:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0f889b4ed95a7144787b2b527e1364297eaded49', 'message': "Hyper-V: properly handle shared storage

The Hyper-V driver has a few issues when attempting to use shared
storage for the instance files, which are addressed by this patch.

This patch may be splitted, but since there are a lot of small changes,
it seemed easier to track by having only one patch.

Migration issues
----------------
In case of migrations, we attempt to move the instance files without
checking whether shared storage is used. Note that the block_migration
flag is completely ignored.

After a live migration is performed, we always try to delete the
instance files. Also, if the migration fails, the destination node is
not cleaned up, as the HyperVLiveMigrateData object is not used at the
moment.

Image/path handling issues
--------------------------
The image cache operation uses thread locks, for which reason it is
prone to race conditions when using shared storage. Switching to file
locks would solve this issue.

Also, the image cache cleanup worker can cause issues in this case,
as it only checks for local instances and file timestamps (which are
updated by this periodic task). For this reason, it may try to delete
base images used by other nodes. Simply updating the timestamp of the
image file whenever we want to 'fetch' it would avoid this issue.

Using UNC paths for the instance path does not work either. The driver
will fail to fetch the available space. Also, it will not build the
remote instance path properly when trying to move files during
migrations.

Closes-Bug: #1565895

Change-Id: I0ac0a2d2e7a8771024a486dd5931bd05b1ecd074

commit_message:
Hyper-V: properly handle shared storage during migrations

In case of migrations, we attempt to move the instance files without
checking whether shared storage is used. Note that the block_migration
flag is ignored.

After a live migration is performed, we always try to delete the
instance files. Also, if the migration fails, the destination node is
not cleaned up, as the HyperVLiveMigrateData object is not used at the
moment.

This change addresses those issues.

Partial-Bug: #1565895

Change-Id: I0ac0a2d2e7a8771024a486dd5931bd05b1ecd074

commit_message:
Call addCleanup(delete_server) immediately after resize server

addCleanup(delete_server) should be called immediately after
resizing server, otherwize if something goes wrong in the
following steps, the testcase will return without deleting server,
and thus may affect other resize testcases

Change-Id: Iaa51549f169414a24d622d0b31c983c9d0751176

commit_message:
Enable log collection after functional testing

This change enables log collection within the gate so that further analysis
on gate tasks can be performed post build. This is very useful when
debugging problems.

Change-Id: I64ba550208a690a784dbad8a3b871d0c1d703612
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server refs/changes/68/362568/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

commit_message:
Fix tables layout

Tables don't fit into browser window when names are too long.
This patch fixes it using Horison WrappingColumn class.

Change-Id: I82e4b30c53052ef45c42dd77fb0c10fd4ee6734e
Closes-Bug: #1616945

commit_message:
Provide fallback prompt function for current osc-lib

Leaving the pw_func uninitialize in osc-lib turned out to be a
bad idea as the test to prompt in setup_auth() doesn't check
for a callback of None.

Also, release note

Change-Id: I8f875fa8a942d02a040238359ee22c603a4e5956
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/98/362498/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Aspects hooking to package load event

Now aspects are notified of the package load event during the
class schema generation, and they are able to invoke method
of the 'Modifier' python-backed class that is supposed to modify
code of the MuranoPL class.

The example policy is extended with the rule that is intended for
changing default value of the property to demonstrate aspect
hooking to the package load event.

Change-Id: I899941a3dae83022330d1a06ccd87f2d61d4f9f9
Partially-implements: bp application-policies
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/83/358683/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from murano.common import aspects _apply_aspects(exc, cls)def _apply_aspects(exc, class_): aspect_objects = aspects.init_aspects(exc) if aspect_objects: notifier = aspects.init_notifier(exc) exc.run(notifier.type, 'onPackageLoad', notifier, (), {'aspects': aspect_objects, 'class_': class_})

commit_message:
Don't calculate redis server twice

We calculate redis server in both get_ip_by_key and _get_client,
and it is not necessary

Closes-Bug: #1617184

commit_message:
Correct dragonflow reraising of exception

When an exception was caught and rethrown, it should call 'raise'
without any arguments because it shows the place where an
exception occured initially instead of place where the exception
re-raised.

Change-Id: I56600399e798ff9283ebd50ad082db66122c3dc6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/10/360910/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: except Exception as e: raise e

commit_message:
Allow unauthenticated packages via puppet provider

After MOS cluster deployment APT configuration allows installation
packages coming from unauthenticated DEB repositories. This is a
security risk because packages installed from unsigned APT
repositories are subject to various threats.

This change will move the option to the puppet provider used during
the deploy and leave APT configuration secure as it should be.

Change-Id: I20ade67e108f0d6666d386b6e00e0cb18df5c571
Closes-Bug: #1594699
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <mmalchuk@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Enable log collection after functional testing

This change enables log collection within the gate so that further analysis
on gate tasks can be performed post build. This is very useful when
debugging problems.

Change-Id: I79d98754d50febdf9b8f39f412a2e9fa1c10c36a
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server refs/changes/36/362536/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

commit_message:
Enforce upper-constraints when building ramdisks

Currently, building ramdisks installs ironic-python-agent without any
upper-constraints. This causes the package to be installed with newer,
untested dependencies.

This commits introduces a tool to generate a local upper-constraints
file based on predefined strategies (below). Additionally, the fallback
to the openstack/requirements uses the URL defined in tox.ini instead of
redefining it. This prevents having to keep track of two separate
variables when releasing.

upper-constraints lookup strategies (in order):

  * UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE points to a local file
  * UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE points to a URL
  * /opt/stack/new/requirements/upper-constraints.txt
  * upper-constraints.txt from openstack/requirements git repository

Partial-bug: #1616554
Change-Id: Ib5c0c57cafdb6ffd7456e61f3b1bb5fa57520e5a
(cherry picked from commit a0ca6ce157b8a84f282d8abbdd27c75f48d991ff)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/93/360793/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IPA_ROOT=$(readlink -f $(dirname $0)/../../)# Everything from ${IPA_ROOT} will be available under /tmp/ironic-python-agent in Docker cd ${IPA_ROOT} imagebuild/common/generate_upper_constraints.sh ${IPA_ROOT}/upper-constraints.txt

commit_message:
Enable log collection after functional testing

This change enables log collection within the gate so that further analysis
on gate tasks can be performed post build. This is very useful when
debugging problems.

Change-Id: I984bc41f1db7cc7228aaf9623213dded4925e2da
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cinder refs/changes/46/362546/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

Enable Sahara panel in Horizon

This change adds an option to deploy the data-processing panel
in Horizon.

commit_message:
Enable log collection after functional testing

This change enables log collection within the gate so that further analysis
on gate tasks can be performed post build. This is very useful when
debugging problems.

Change-Id: I3a91bb057980879a3ead9d9fb04db22832aeba1f
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_barbican refs/changes/44/362544/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

revisions:

commit_message:
Install crc16 when redis is enabled

The current devstack script will only install crc16 for redis server.
However, it will fail the compute node using redis. The redis db drvier
needs crc16 [1], no matter if it is a redis server node.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/dragonflow/blob/master/dragonflow/db/drivers/redis_calckey.py

Change-Id: I7e9c07b700cf6b5b4dbd0ff9f8ae01a93b04ebe6
Related-bug: #1606457
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/16/362516/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo pip install crc16

commit_message:
OSSN-0070: bandit version < 1.1.0 have possible XSS

Closes-bug: #1612988
Change-Id: Ibdbbc02f8f2f4ab33fc7a1c33f6c2a89d2380c81
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/93/355493/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Bandit versions lower than 1.1.0 do not escape HTML in issue reports --- ### Summary ### Bandit versions lower than 1.1.0 had a bug in the HTML report formatter that did not escape HTML in issue context snippets. This could lead to an XXS if HTML reports were hosted as part of a CI pipeline. ### Affected Services / Software ### Bandit: < 1.1.0 ### Discussion ### Bandit versions lower than 1.1.0 had a bug in the HTML report formatter that did not escape HTML in issue context snippets. This could lead to an XXS attack if HTML reports were hosted as part of a CI pipeline because HTML in the source code would be copied verbatim into the report. For example: import subprocess subprocess.Popen("<script>alert(1)</script>", shell=True) Would result in the "<script>alert(1)</script>" being inserted into the report HTML. This issue could allow for arbitrary code injection into CI/CD pipelines that feature accessible HTML reports generated from Bandit runs. ### Recommended Actions ### Update bandit to version 1.1.0 or greater. ### Contacts / References ### Author: Tim Kelsey <tim.kelsey@hpe.com> This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0063 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/bandit/+bug/1612988 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg CVE: N/A

commit_message:
Enable log collection after functional testing

This change enables log collection within the gate so that further analysis
on gate tasks can be performed post build. This is very useful when
debugging problems.

Change-Id: I76f771e8ca3a434fc3fd710a9ff035cb2bfad182
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-haproxy_server refs/changes/37/362537/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

commit_message:
Improve usability of booting guest with SR-IOV

This blueprint describes the extension of the glance image properties in order
to be able to specify a VIF model of type SR-IOV for network attachments.  This
feature improve the usability of SR-IOV network devices.  Currently booting a
guest with NIC SR-IOV attachment requires the user to first create a Neutron
port making it a multi-steps procedure.

Change-Id: Icdb13f9750b6c24b86740df64f5b5493f214376c
Implements: blueprint image-vif-model-sriov
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/64/304564/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================== Improve usability of booting guest with SR-IOV ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/image-vif-model-sriov This blueprint describes the extension of the glance image properties in order to be able to specify a VIF model of type SR-IOV for network attachments. This feature improve the usability of SR-IOV network devices. Currently booting a guest with NIC SR-IOV attachment requires the user to first create a Neutron port making it a multi-steps procedure. Problem description =================== Nova supports attaching an SR-IOV NIC device to an instance. This process involves the creation of a Neutron port before launching a guest. For example, a user would do the following for booting an instance with an SR-IOV network device: :: $ NETID=`neutron net-list | grep default | awk '{print $2}'` $ neutron port-create $NETID --binding:vnic-type direct --name p-direct $ PORTID=`neutron port-list | grep "p-direct" | awk '{print $2}'` $ nova boot --image=guest.img --flavor=small --nic port-id=$PORTID guest0 This blueprint proposes to eliminate the intermediate step of creating a Neutron port by having Nova do the work on the behalf of the user. The goal is to improve the usability of booting instances with SR-IOV network devices. Better usability can limit errors (specifying wrong arguments) or limit race conditions (such as multiple instances trying to bind with the same port). Nova already creates neutron port for requested networks that are specified when spawning an instance. The use case of creating a neutron port for an SR-IOV network device shouldn't then be treated any differently. The usability of nova should be consistent, whichever port type is used. Use Cases --------- A user wants to launch a guest with an SR-IOV network device and they want nova to create the neutron port for him like it does for any other type of ports. Proposed change =============== Glance has been extended to support specifying the VIF model associated with an image (see [0] and [1] for more information). This results in the instances that are booted with this specific image to be loaded with the corresponding network drivers. For example, a VIF model for an e1000 network device is configured as follow: :: $ glance image-update --property vif_model=e1000 myimage.img This proposal suggests to augment this mechanism in order to support a VIF model of type SR-IOV. There are no glance changes required since the properties are specified using opaque strings and they are not validated by glance. Currently booting an instance with an SR-IOV port demands that a neutron port is pre-populated before requesting booting such an instance. The nova compute API then creates a corresponding PCI request for this particular port. The PCI request is then used by the scheduler for selecting a compute that has hardware resources to accommodate SR-IOV networking. In the end a PCI device (based on the PCI request) will be allocate on the target compute. In the case that interests us, the same logic needs to be applied for guests that are using an image that specifies an SR-IOV VIF model. Therefore we suggest that the nova compute API gets modified consistently. Meaning that the nova compute API will create a PCI requests for each of the network requested that are specified with the SR-IOV VIF model. The nova layer that interacts with neutron already supports the creation of ports following the requested networks specified when booting an instance. This piece of code will be modified for supporting port of type SR-IOV by specifying to neutron that the port is of type "{'binding:vnic_type': 'direct'}". The handling of the VIF model embedded in an image is already supported in the nova libvirt driver. This component (more specifically the VIF objects) will be modified to support SR-IOV so that the corresponding network device can be properly specified in the instance XML (the format is dictated by libvirt). Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ludovic.beliveau (ludovic.beliveau@windriver.com) Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Change the nova.compute.API object to handle the creation of the PCI request. * Modify the nova.network.neutronv2.API. * Modify the nova.virt.libvirt.vif to handle the specification of SR-IOV VIF model via the image properties. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= As usual, tox unit tests will have to be written to properly test this new feature. This feature can't be tested in a virtual environment and require servers with NIC that supports SR-IOV. Specific tests could most likely be added to the Intel PCI CI to validate the changes. Documentation Impact ==================== The glance user documentation guide will need to be modified (http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/common/cli_manage_images.html). References ========== [0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21527/4 [1] http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/common/cli_manage_images.html History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced but no changes merged. * - Newton - Re-proposed.

commit_message:
Boot argument to specify network VIF model

This blueprint describes the addition of a new boot argument to the network
options in order to improve the usability of using multiple types of network
drivers for network interfaces of the guests.  Currently openstack supports
configuring the network driver by embedding it in the image properties.

Change-Id: I3d6179a8fe2eb4f49f2c6a10ba324bb119c78cbe
Implements: blueprint network-requested-vif-model
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/82/304582/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Boot argument to specify network VIF model ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/network-requested-vif-model This blueprint describes the addition of a new boot argument to the network options in order to improve the usability of using multiple types of network drivers for network interfaces of the guests. Currently openstack supports configuring the network driver by embedding it in the image properties. Problem description =================== In openstack today it is possible to configure the network device driver that will be used for the network interfaces of the guests. This configuration is per image, meaning that all the guests launched with a given image will use the same network device driver (for e.g.: virtio, e1000, etc.). The driver configured in the image is specified to libvirt when launching the guests. For example, an image can be specified to use the e1000 driver with the following command (for more information see [0] and [1]): :: $ glance image-update --property \ --property hw_vif_model=e1000 \ f16-x86_64-openstack-sda There are two shortcomings this this approach: * A user that needs to deploy different guests that uses different network drivers has to build one image per driver. * A guest using this image is limited to using only one network driver even if it's using multiple network attachment. This blueprint propose to address these shortcomings by adding a boot parameter option for specifying an optional VIF model for each requested network. The goal is to improve usability and flexibility for the user when launching guests using different VIF model. Use Cases --------- A user wants to launch a guest with multiple network devices using different network device drivers (for example one network interface with e1000 and another with virtio). Proposed change =============== The proposed solution is to extend the Nova compute REST API to support an extra parameter ‘vif-model’ in the list of requested networks. The 'vif-model' is an opaque string. The value is a valid model. The supported models must be in line with the hypervisor capabilities. The python-novaclient would be extended to support the new argument 'vif-model' that can be associated with each requested network specified ("--nic"). For example: :: $ nova boot --image=guest.img --flavor=small \ --nic net-id=$NETID,vif-model=e1000 \ --nic net-id=$NETID,vif-model=virtio guest0 The VIF model would then be stored in the nova.objects.NetworkRequest object in a new field ‘vif_model' after the REST API call is received in nova. The VIF model needs to be persistent so that when an instance is re-created (for e.g. after a migration), the correct VIF model is used. Note that currently the original list of requested networks is not persitent in the database. Since neutron is not interested in the VIF model, it wouldn't make much sense to transport this extra information up to neutron. Currently all the networking information associated with an instance is kept in the instance database table in the InstanceInfoCache.NetworkModel object. As the name suggest, this is a cache and it is built based on fetching the port information from neutron. Basically the NetworkModel (more specifically the VIF objects) is stored as a flat json string object based on the ports information received from neutron. The proposition is to persist the VIF model in the InstanceInfoCache.NetworkModel object. However the cache is not currently able to support extra fields that are not present in the neutron ports. The current logic is to just overwrite the cache with the latest port information. Extra care will need to be taken in order to not overwrite the VIF model whenever the instance is saved with an updated cache information. The nova neutronv2 layer is responsible to build the network information cache based on the information received from neutron. It will need to be modified in order to not blindly overwrite all the VIF objects in the cache and smartly only updates the fields that have changed for a given port. This way the VIF model will be preserved even when the cache is updated. For this proposal, the VIF model will only be implemented for libvirt. Once the framework is in place, it's relatively easy for another virtualization layer to use the VIF model information that is now stored with the instance. The nova libvirt layer will be modified accordingly. This layer will access the VIF model information from the InstanceInfoCache.NetworkModel when an instance is launched. More precisely, the VIF model will be set on the VIF objects that will later on be used for constructing the instance XML. Based on the work done for supporting VIF model per image (see [0]), the is_vif_model_valid_for_virt() will be re-used in order to validate the VIF model before launching a guest. If the VIF model is not specified when booting the instance, the default driver will then be used. Alternatives ------------ Instead of storing the VIF model in the network information cache in the instance object (consequently in the instance table in the database) for persistence, it could also be stored in neutron in the port object. The nova layer that interacts with neutron (neutronv2 api) could be modified in order to specify the VIF model in the port profile when creating the port. However this solution imposes dependancies on external openstack project. For the VIF model persistence, it would also be possible to store it in a new member in the Instance object instead of storing it in the network information cache. This would allow to save the original list of requested networks (with their options) with the instance. The problem is that we would have two distinct networks related members in the Instance to maintain and it could bring more confusion than anything else. There is a limitation currently when specifying a VIF model in an image. It’s possible that a guest is launched on a compute where the hypervisor doesn't support specifying the VIF model for a network attachment. This proposal would also display the same limitation. A generic solution could be to add logic in the scheduler to filter out computes that do not support this feature. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The following changes are expected for the nova compute REST API: * The /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers GET method needs to return the VIF models for an an instance. * The /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers POST method needs to support the new ‘vif-model’ argument. The proposed change necessitate to add a new microversion to the REST API. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Changes in python-novaclient are required. We recommend to only support this feature through the command line interface for now. But it's also possible to extend horizon as such. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ludovic.beliveau (ludovic.beliveau@windriver.com) Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Extend the Nova compute REST API. * Extend python-novaclient. * Modify the nova.objects.NetworkRequest object. * Modify the nova.network.model.VIF object to allow persistency of the new requested_network field. * Modify the neutronv2 layer to correctly save the VIF model when the network information cache is refreshed. * Modify the nova.virt.libvirt.LibvirtDriver to handle VIF model. Dependencies ============ The python-novaclient will need to be modified to accept the command line argument for specifying the VIF models. Testing ======= As usual, tox unit tests will have to be written to properly test this new feature. This feature can be tested in a virtual environment and doesn't require any specific hardware for testing it. Documentation Impact ==================== Since the nova REST API is impacted, the corresponding documentation will require to be changed (http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html). The Nova command line documentation also require changes (http://docs.openstack.org/cli-reference/nova.html). References ========== [0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21527/ [1] http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/common/cli_manage_images.html [2] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsNICSModel History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced but no changes merged. * - Newton - Re-proposed.

commit_message:
Upgrade ceph-mon

Adds a pre-requisite software deployment to the pacemaker scenario
upgrade which, before the openstack services are upgraded,
upgrades the ceph-mon daemon from Hammer to Jewel.

Change-Id: I9855d80a6ae156b4a9e0409c3c927068b9db95a0

commit_message:
Add an example for a minimum devstack setup

This change introduces a minimal devstack "local.conf" file for
x86 systems. It's the first of many possible scenarios. They will
differ to the guides in a way that their focus is for experienced users.
Those users want to reproduce issues or test WIP features in certain
scenarios.

Change-Id: I37738b835a6c78bf2c47f4b9fc334d2b526b677c

commit_message:
Use assertEqual() instead of assertDictEqual()

OpenStack now has dropped support for python 2.6 and lower.and assertEqual()
in testtools is able to handle dicts comparation so we do't need to call
assertDictEqual() for dicts any more.
So we can simply use assertEqual() instead of assertDictEqual().
This will unify the unit test code, and will also simplify the development
of unit tests.

Change-Id: I47a0110ec272da8bc5eb780f2bc3d5560fc9f0e0

commit_message:
Removed authenticate() method

Functionality is now available via tokenIssue() and catalogList().

Change-Id: I9871304694286d1d0f4f6c395074ebd6d8f2e2c8

commit_message:
Added catalogList() method to keystone API

Given a token, this method will return a promise which resolves to
the service catalog.

Change-Id: If1b7832f5e5e48902e0ef31d28384bb9aeab2fd5

commit_message:
Added tokenRevoke() method to keystone API.

This method permits the revocation of an auth token, whether by
the auth token itself, or by an admin token.

Change-Id: Ia80fd70986410b364351bffeaa5823a36d25d2cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/js-openstack-lib refs/changes/37/358037/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function tokenRevoke (token, adminToken = null) { return { method: 'DELETE', matcher: 'http://192.168.99.99/identity_v2_admin/v3/auth/tokens', headers: { 'X-Subject-Token': token, 'X-Auth-Token': adminToken || token }, response: { status: 204 } }; } tokenIssue as tokenIssue, tokenRevoke as tokenRevoke

subject: Fixed header bug in fetchMock

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-23 17:25:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/js-openstack-lib/commit/a32b8420ccdb1e6662ae9bc98c3460390155b660', 'message': "Fixed header bug in fetchMock

Fetch-mock doesn't sanely match against a Headers() instance, whose
implementation varies due to isomorphic-fetch. Here we deconstruct the instance
back into a map, so that the actual fetch() request is properly handled.

commit_message:
Fixed header bug in fetchMock

Fetch-mock doesn't sanely match against a Headers() instance, whose
implementation varies due to isomorphic-fetch. Here we deconstruct the instance
back into a map, so that the actual fetch() request is properly handled.

Change-Id: Ie99ca23a6cf75c48c8762e7de36aee71ef819b7f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/js-openstack-lib refs/changes/53/359353/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // BUG: Fetch-mock doesn't sanely match against a Headers() instance, whose // implementation varies due to isomorphic-fetch. Here we deconstruct the instance // back into a map, so that the actual fetch() request is properly handled. const headers = {}; if (request.headers) { if (request.headers.forEach) { // Isomorphic-fetch exposes forEach(). request.headers.forEach((value, key) => { headers[key] = value; }); } else if (request.headers.entries) { // ES2015 exposes entries(). Sadly, Babel does not support yield. for (let [key, value] of request.headers.entries()) { headers[key] = value; } } } headers

commit_message:
Added tokenIssue() method to keystone API.

This method handles sending an authorization request against the
keystone API, and returns the issued Authorization Token. At this
time it only supports the password authorization plugin. Additional
use cases should be provided by third-party developers.

It is the long term intent that this method will deprecate the
authorize() method, in order to provide a consistently idempotent
implementation.

Change-Id: If1368bcdae251606d2e03043345cd4fc6f0b8b80

commit_message:
Keystone authenticate() now uses resolved service endpoint.

Authenticate is now called against an endpoint whose version is
known, and thus can be more easily supported.

Change-Id: I6e5dd64ac7ccc91d0a35630335f301377d87079c

commit_message:
Added serviceEndpoint() method.

This method will return the service endpoint of the current supported
keystone version.

Change-Id: I3af0faf5191b89cfd7a266edfe0bd044d6dd02ce

commit_message:
Added version() resource.

This resource will attempt to resolve a supported API version from
the versions available on the Keystone API.

Change-Id: Icca49d3c124fb9526aa4316290b475d95cfda2ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/js-openstack-lib refs/changes/51/356751/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: afterEach(fetchMock.restore); describe("version()", () => { const devstackConfig = aCloudsConfig('devstack').clouds.devstack; const authUrl = devstackConfig.auth.auth_url; it("Should return a supported version of the keystone API.", (done) => { const keystone = new Keystone(devstackConfig); fetchMock.get(authUrl, keystoneMockData['/']); keystone.version() .then((version) => { expect(version.id).toEqual('v3.7'); done(); }) .catch((error) => { expect(error).toBeNull(); done(); }); }); it("Should throw an exception if no supported version is found.", (done) => { const keystone = new Keystone(devstackConfig); const responseData = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(keystoneMockData['/'])); // Remove the first (supported) version. responseData.versions.values.shift(); fetchMock.get(authUrl, responseData); keystone.version() .then((version) => { expect(version).toBeNull(); done(); }) .catch((error) => { expect(error).not.toBeNull(); done(); }); }); it("Should cache its results", (done) => { const keystone = new Keystone(devstackConfig); fetchMock.get(authUrl, keystoneMockData['/']); keystone.version() .then(() => { // Validate that the mock has only been invoked once expect(fetchMock.calls(authUrl).length).toEqual(1); return keystone.version(); }) .then(() => { expect(fetchMock.calls(authUrl).length).toEqual(1); done(); }) .catch((error) => { expect(error).toBeNull(); done(); }); }); });

commit_message:
Created versions() resource for Keystone

This resource returns a (caching) promise, which will eventually
resolve to the list of versions published at the auth_url. It also
updates the unit tests to draw from a consolidated set of mock data.

Change-Id: I0d0de5b6ef6a1e3d1f5daa40a88ec3d799c43a64

commit_message:
Fixes TypeError on Client instantiation

When instantiating novaclient with kwargs or named attributes, the 'password'
field is duplicated due to an overwrite on the __init__ method of Client v2.
This patch pops out the password field when it's passed and no api_key is
provided.

Co-Authored-By: Pavel Kholkin <pkholkin@mirantis.com>

Closes-bug: #1511417

Change-Id: Id8310eccef5f0f9a2983e25dd35541d1eb0efe86

commit_message:
Rename FUEL_PROPOSED_REPO_URL

Right now this var is used only for octane installation and
misleading people with other proposed-related variables.

Change-Id: Ie3611482c87e7d183c85fba39cde3daaf2489ab4

commit_message:
Tests: use fakes.HTTPRequest in compute tests

In wsgi controllers tests fakes.HTTPRequest and webob.Request are used.
fakes.HTTPRequest is the descendant of webob.Request defined in nova
test codebase. To have single point of modification it's better to have
common class for controllers tests.

This change replaces webob.Request to fakes.HTTPRequest and updates
blank method signature with respect to actual webob.Request.blank
method.

Change-Id: I043b9cf4426ec1d2c9b178a6ceacb74fc113e21b
Related-Bug: #1610153

commit_message:
Change assertTrue(isinstance()) by optimal assert

Some of tests use different method of assertTrue(isinstance(A, B))
or assertEqual(type(A), B)
The correct way is to use assertIsInstance(A, B) provided by testtools

Change-Id: I12eaca68ce9951c8f2ed0bb6a5098ec5a5522484

commit_message:
Updating DOC on floating IPs change

Changing documentation on how floating IPs work from Newton on.

Change-Id: Ic2a30232c1895873b3d5b3719de5761b36a9fab2
Implements-bp: refactor-use-floating-ip
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/28/362328/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: has two options for ensuring that the instances in the node groups templates that requires floating IPs gain a floating IP address: group that requires floating IPs directly. From Newton changes were made to allow the coexistence of clusters using floating IPs and clusters using fixed IPs. If ``use_floating_ips`` is True it means that the floating IPs can be used by Sahara to spawn clusters. But, differently from previous versions, this does not mean that all instances in the cluster must have floating IPs and that all clusters must use floating IPs. It is possible in a single Sahara deploy to have clusters setup using fixed IPs, clusters using floating IPs and cluster that use both.
deleted_lines: has two options for ensuring that all instances gain a floating IP address: group directly. .. warning:: When using floating IP addresses for management (``use_floating_ips=True``) **every** instance in the cluster must have a floating IP address, otherwise sahara will not be able to utilize that cluster.

commit_message:
Fix cluster status update after CHECK/RECOVER

After executing CHECK/RECOVER actions, we will re-evaluate the cluster's
status based on the status of its member nodes, NOT the action per se.

Change-Id: I49429b39b4f7c6df51c28fe6d08b3e34a915f517

commit_message:
Add networks to quota's update json-schema when network quota enabled

The enable of network quota is configurable. But the json-schema of quota
update won't be updated accroding configuration. This leads to user can't
update network quota from API.

This patch add network quota when it's enabled.

Change-Id: I922525bfe55c42d2bf187c3bcd30536c8adf1c4f
Closes-Bug: #1606740

subject: [Reports] In charts, fix setting red color for non-error metric
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-22 11:28:01.000000000', 'files': ['rally/ui/templates/task/directive_widget.js'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/d7a16c2ed2652e5bbdeafb23aa5ccdb7e136b051', 'message': '[Reports] In charts, fix setting red color for non-error metric

There is a bug in charts StackedArea and Lines, which appears
in case if there are a >= 9 metrics - in this case metric #9
gets red color, which is also set for failed_duration.
As result, tehere are 2 metrics with same color on chart.

This fixes the bug by introducing standard way of color

Change-Id: Ideaed933f3fdb5b3465124fc5b8ae730119cb08c
'}]
commit_message:
[Reports] In charts, fix setting red color for non-error metric

There is a bug in charts StackedArea and Lines, which appears
in case if there are a >= 9 metrics - in this case metric #9
gets red color, which is also set for failed_duration.
As result, tehere are 2 metrics with same color on chart.

This fixes the bug by introducing standard way of color
generation for all charts, which skips failure-color (red)
when generating next color.

Change-Id: Ideaed933f3fdb5b3465124fc5b8ae730119cb08c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/66/358566/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: driver.pre_live_migration migrate_data is always an object
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-21 10:01:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0ecedae517a11c6f6bc46e5039b971c87062efa8', 'message': 'driver.pre_live_migration migrate_data is always an object

The driver function pre_live_migration() has only 1 caller:
ComputeManager.pre_live_migration(), which always passes a
LiveMigrateData object to the driver. This is easy to prove as
ComputeManager.pre_live_migration() explicitly checks if migrate_data
is an object, and assigns it the return value of
LiveMigrateData.detect_implementation() if not.
detect_implementation() can only return a subclass of LiveMigrateData.
It will raise an exception if it is passed None.

This change removes handling of the case where migrate_data is None or
otherwise not a LiveMigrateData object from all driver implementations
of pre_live_migration().

commit_message:
driver.pre_live_migration migrate_data is always an object

The driver function pre_live_migration() has only 1 caller:
ComputeManager.pre_live_migration(), which always passes a
LiveMigrateData object to the driver. This is easy to prove as
ComputeManager.pre_live_migration() explicitly checks if migrate_data
is an object, and assigns it the return value of
LiveMigrateData.detect_implementation() if not.
detect_implementation() can only return a subclass of LiveMigrateData.
It will raise an exception if it is passed None.

This change removes handling of the case where migrate_data is None or
otherwise not a LiveMigrateData object from all driver implementations
of pre_live_migration().

Change-Id: I9d46019e06dc2b59f7b2ddf7c57c333809cbc94b

commit_message:
Handling defaults for pxe_bootfile_name and pxe_config_template moved to puppet

This change hardcodes UEFI boot files to iPXE. This does not change anything for us,
as previously we would default to ELILO, which we don't ship and/or configure.

Change-Id: Ib43f6c9f25d658392e062cd76f25b9c8bd12e5b8
Depends-On: Ic6844bf313a08b8481d3474185d08d878ff52b5a

commit_message:
Workflows to run validations

This commit adds a workflow to run ansible validations.

Validations can be run individually or by group, and the result is sent
over the specified zaqar queue.

Change-Id: Iba8b210c83e94eaa340d34e17ad2b0278ecc4e53
Depends-On: I807fed12e9a42a71c130f393370ff4152831c27b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/99/353899/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -e set -o pipefail VALIDATION_FILE=$1 if [[ -z "$VALIDATION_FILE" ]]; then echo "Missing required validation file" exit 1 fi if [[ ! -r "$VALIDATION_FILE" ]]; then echo "Can not find validation at $VALIDATION_FILE" exit 1 fi DYNAMIC_INVENTORY_SCRIPT=$(which tripleo-ansible-inventory) # Make sure ssh is not asking interactively for hosts it can't check the key # authenticity export ANSIBLE_HOST_KEY_CHECKING=False ansible-playbook -i $DYNAMIC_INVENTORY_SCRIPT $VALIDATION_FILE

commit_message:
Add existing volumes when using pre-provisioned credentials

When using pre-provisioned credentials, the tenant may have volumes
other than those created in the testcase and so will make
test_volume_list_details_pagination and test_volume_list_pagination
fail unexpectedly. This is to fix it.

Change-Id: I997792dcf26a2ce07ec6e0de0b0557a0c260ea59
Closes-Bug: #1612097

added_lines: # NOTE(zhufl): When using pre-provisioned credentials, the tenant # may have volumes other than those created upper. existing_volumes = cls.client.list_volumes()['volumes'] cls.volume_list.extend(existing_volumes) cls.volume_id_list.extend([vol['id'] for vol in existing_volumes])

commit_message:
Update oslo.messaging to 5.6.0

- Add pifpaf as a testing dependency

commit_message:
Add --wait to iptables calls

This change updates the calls that we us in the ocf scripts to determine
if the rules are present to include the -w flag to prevent the scripts
from failing if another iptables call is currently running. It has been
reported that this can occur when the ocf scripts are running in
parallel to the puppet deployment (firewall task)

Change-Id: Ia603f5643720a5fa5407de36ca75830a7c3f57fa
Closes-Bug: #1605540
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/53/355953/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: until $(iptables -nvL --wait | grep -q 'temporary RMQ block') || [ $tries -eq 0 ]; do iptables --wait -I INPUT -p tcp -m tcp --dport ${OCF_RESKEY_node_port} -m state --state NEW,RELATED,ESTABLISHED \ for i in $(iptables -nvL --wait --line-numbers | awk '/temporary RMQ block/ {print $1}'); do iptables --wait -D INPUT -p tcp -m tcp --dport ${OCF_RESKEY_node_port} -m state --state NEW,RELATED,ESTABLISHED \
deleted_lines: until $(iptables -nvL | grep -q 'temporary RMQ block') || [ $tries -eq 0 ]; do iptables -I INPUT -p tcp -m tcp --dport ${OCF_RESKEY_node_port} -m state --state NEW,RELATED,ESTABLISHED \ for i in $(iptables -nvL --line-numbers | awk '/temporary RMQ block/ {print $1}'); do iptables -D INPUT -p tcp -m tcp --dport ${OCF_RESKEY_node_port} -m state --state NEW,RELATED,ESTABLISHED \
